awd_titl_txt: III: Small: A Submodular Framework for Scalable Graph Matching with Performance Guarantees
awd_abstract_narration:
Graphs are a natural and convenient abstraction for modeling structures arising in a broad spectrum of science and engineering disciplines. In many applications, a key problem is to align a pair of graphs (or "embed" one into the other). This is known as graph matching, and it frequently emerges in machine vision (e.g., landmark matching), learning (knowledge graphs), and graph mining; computational biology (protein-protein interactions); social sciences (social / organizational networks); and electronic circuit layout verification, to name a few areas.  Graph matching is a computationally demanding problem, yet modern applications easily generate graphs with millions of vertices. In that regime, there is a pressing need for approximation algorithms which are both theoretically sound and highly scalable. This project considers graph matching from a fresh perspective -- through the lens of submodular optimization. The proposed research will yield exciting new theoretical and methodological insights that will also inform other walks of combinatorial optimization and its applications.  In parallel with the research activities, the PIs will contribute to state-wide efforts to broaden participation in computing, via guest lectures in introductory engineering courses, and teaming up with a nonprofit that trains K-12 teachers to empower them to teach coding and computational thinking.

Existing graph matching approximations based on relaxing the combinatorial constraints either do not scale well, or fail to provide performance guarantees (except in special cases). None of these directly tackles the combinatorial nature of the problem; the conventional wisdom being that the difficulty stems from the constraints, not the cost function. In preliminary work, the PIs have established that graph matching can be equivalently reformulated as minimizing a submodular function over the intersection of a pair of partition matroids. Using this preliminary result as a stepping stone, this project is focused on designing successive submodular approximation algorithms that feature both theoretical performance guarantees and scalability; hard and soft graph matching (via continuous extension); validation using real-world data; and leveraging the practical insights gained through validation to close the loop and drive further methodological and algorithmic developments.  Breaking from the mold, the approach embraces combinatorial optimization using a judicious combination of discrete and continuous optimization tools which promises to go a long way towards improving the state-of-art for this fundamental problem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

In this project we studied core problems in the broad area of graph matching and mining. We showed that graph matching can be formulated as maximizing a monotone supermodular function subject to matroid intersection constraints. We leveraged this insight to design an iterative graph matching algorithm that generates a sequence of strictly feasible and monotonically improving matching iterates. We motivated ``soft’’ graph matching as a means of identifying classes of topologically invariant subgraphs which cannot be revealed by hard correspondences and proposed a new soft matching formulation which can be interpreted as the tightest convex relaxation of hard graph matching in a certain sense. On graph mining, we formally proved that two recurring characteristics of real-world graphs, namely heavy-tailed degree distributions and large clustering coefficients, imply the existence of substantially large vertex neighborhoods with high edge-density. We then leveraged what we learned from the graph alignment problem to explore new approaches for dense subgraph mining. We focused on the Densest-𝑘-Subgraph problem (DkS), which seeks to find a subset of 𝑘 vertices such that the sum of the edge weights in the corresponding subgraph is maximized. The problem is known to be NP-hard and also very difficult to approximate in the worst case. We reformulated DkS as minimizing a submodular function subject to a cardinality constraint. Exploiting the fact that submodular functions possess a convex, continuous extension (the Lovaśz extension), we proposed to minimize the Lovaśz extension over the convex hull of the cardinality constraints and showed that for DkS the Lovaśz extension can be written out analytically. We also extended our DkS approach to mining triangle-dense subgraphs, i.e., the Triangle-Densest-k-Subgraph (TDkS) problem, and showed that TDkS can also yield better DkS solutions. We justified this using the Kruskal-Katona theorem and additional results that we derived. Bridging two different paradigms in dense subgraph mining, we showed that the optimal quasi-clique (OQC) formulation can be used to explore the entire spectrum of densest subgraphs of all distinct sizes by appropriately varying a single hyperparameter, thereby forging an intimate link with the DkS problem. Our findings show that OQC not only extracts high quality (near)-cliques, but also large and loosely connected subgraphs that exhibit well defined local community structure. The latter – surprising – discovery is particularly intriguing, since OQC is not explicitly geared towards community detection. Finally, we also considered a continuous reformulation of the binary quadratic DkS problem which incorporates a diagonal loading term. We proved that this continuous relaxation is tight for a range of diagonal loading parameters and studied the impact of the diagonal loading parameter on the optimization landscape. Towards these ends, we derived non-trivial extensions of the classic results, such as the Motzkin-Straus theorem. On the algorithmic side, we proposed a Frank-Wolfe algorithm which stands out from the competition in terms of subgraph density, computational complexity, and ability to scale up to very large datasets.

Broader Impacts

Our graph matching and mining methods have many applications in diverse fields. For example, we leveraged graph mining tools to learn concise representations of entities and relations in a drug repurposing knowledge base released by Amazon. We employed these representations to perform drug repurposing for Covid-19. Our proposed framework achieved 100% improvement over the best baseline available at that time in the Covid-19 drug repurposing task, and it automatically put dexamethasone (widely used to treat Covid-19 patients) on top of its short-list of recommended drugs. Another contribution that has significant potential for broader impact is our recent work on fairness-aware dense subgraph discovery (DSD). In many applications, it is desirable to extract a dense subgraph that provides fair representation of the diverse subgroups that constitute the vertex set while incurring a small loss in terms of subgraph density. Existing methods for promoting fairness in DSD have important limitations - the associated formulations are NP–hard in the worst case and they do not provide flexible notions of fairness, making it non-trivial to analyze the inherent trade-off between density and fairness. Our methods provide a structured and flexible low-complexity approach to incorporate fairness, accommodating varying fairness levels. We introduced the fairness-induced relative loss in subgraph density as a price of fairness measure to quantify the associated trade-off. We are the first to study such a notion in the context of detecting fair dense subgraphs. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrated that our methods frequently outperform existing solutions. Importantly, they excel in scenarios that previous methods fail, e.g., those with extreme subgroup imbalances, highlighting their effectiveness in extracting fair and dense solutions.

This project has provided several graduate students many opportunities to develop a better understanding of key analytical and computational tools, including optimization, complexity theory, estimation theory, factor analysis, and high-performance computing.
